Hans von Spakovsky, expert on election law, former commissioner of the Federal Election Commission, former prosecutor in the Civil Rights Division of the Department of Justice, enforcing, of all things, voting rights laws. So my question to you is this.  There's litigation going on, and in some states, they're going to re-canvas, and also the president's campaign, depending on the state, like in Wisconsin and so forth, because they were so razor thin, they have the right for potential recount.  What does re-canvas mean?

recanvass is when they quickly go through all the vote totals and ballots that were sent in by election officials from polling places across the state and make sure that all the numbers were correctly totaled up and they want to check their computers.

they want to check their software.  they had some issues like this in michigan.  there's some questions being raised in wisconsin and so forth.  so it really gives an opportunity to the state election boards if they're earnest to say, all right, did we get this right?  That's still going on today, isn't it?
There are state laws that give a candidate, depending on how close the election is, some states under 1% and so forth, the opportunity to an automatic or to request a recount, correct?
In many states, you can get a recount.  Depending on the state, it's either a 1% margin of difference or in some places it's half a percent margin of difference.

No, that's exactly right.  I mean, think how long they're taking right now just to count the ballots.  And when you do a recount, you have to recount every single ballot in the state.

Now, why is this important?  Why is this important as a fundamental matter, as a constitutional matter, and actually for Congress when they meet and determine whether or not the Electoral College votes are the Electoral College votes that they want to certify?

well because look election officials even when they're doing their best they make mistakes having.  all you gotta do is look at the the read the glitch that was just announced in michigan uh... where they initially in a uh... announced that a democrat had won a uh... a race there and then realized the software glitch had misreported things and in fact the republican incumbent had one three three canvases are often do turn up uh... mistakes that were made in totally out the votes and when you do a recount uh... the vote totals often also change uh... because you'll remember mark most of these places are using opti scan paper ballots And sometimes those paper ballots have not been marked exactly the way you're supposed to for them to be read by a computer scanner. So let's look at the state of play as we speak.  We have a significant lawsuit that's been brought in Pennsylvania that the Supreme Court has indicated is very likely to consider that can have an enormous impact on that state.  We have canvassing or re-canvassing taking place in some of these states that are very, very close.  We have the right for a candidate, say the president's campaign, the president, to call for recount in several of these states that are very, very close.  You have Al Gore, who litigated for 37 days in one state, really three counties, but one state, went to the Supreme Court twice.  And yet it seems like Joe Biden, the Democrat Party and everybody else is in a very big hurry to get an answer today.  Isn't it better to go through the process, the constitutional and statutory process to make sure everything is right in every state?

Well, yeah, particularly because the results aren't efficient until election officials and state officials certify the results, and they won't do that until the canvassing, recanvassing has been done, and if a recount has been ordered, they won't do it until the recount has been completed.  And if there is litigation... Serious litigation contesting the outcome, they also are foolish, and I don't think they will, certify the result if, in fact, that litigation could change the outcome.

And the reason why it's foolish is because the final check is the United States Congress.  If some state jumps the gun and significant litigation or recounts aren't completed or so forth, the Congress can reject the electors from that particular state.
